questions.text: An 81-year-old man is brought to the orthopaedic emergency department with chief complaints of severe backache. As per the attendants, he fell at home while walking. There is localised tenderness over the L1 vertebra. Given below is the X-ray of the LS spine of this patient. Which statement is true regarding his underlying metabolic condition and associated pathology?

options.label: A
options.text: DEXA T score of -1.8 in this patient would confirm the diagnosis of osteoporosis

options.label: B
options.text: Kyphoplasty is the treatment of choice for him

options.label: C
options.text: The Serum mineralisation is usually normal

options.label: D
options.text: Vitamin D level of 20 ng/mL in this individual would confirm the diagnosis of osteoporosis

questions.correct_answer: C. The Serum mineralisation is usually normal
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The Serum mineralisation is usually normal In osteoporosis, serum mineralization is usually normal. Calcium, phosphate, and Alkaline phosphatase are usually normal. This patient sustained an osteoporotic L1 compression fracture. Osteoporosis is characterized by decreased bone quantity with normal bone quality. Compression fractures of vertebrae (mostly dorsolumbar region) are the most common type of fragility fracture in patients with osteoporosis. Management of this patient needs proper evaluation to identify the etiology of the fracture and appropriate intervention to rectify the underlying pathology. Evaluation includes bone densitometry and lab testing of Vitamin D and calcium. As per WHO, Osteoporosis is defined by T,-scores 2.5 or greater standard deviations below the peak bone mass of a 25-year-old individual.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. The DEXA T-score less than -2.5 confirms the diagnosis of osteoporosis. Option: B. Kyphoplasty is indicated for recalcitrant cases where severe pain symptoms remain after 6 weeks of nonoperative treatment Option: D . Vitamin D levels are generally low in osteoporotic patients ( <20ng/mL considered deficient); this is not diagnostic. The DEXA scan remains the most accurate and supported diagnostic modality.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman presents in OPD with acute right hip pain since morning. There is no history of road traffic accidents or assaults, or other hip trauma. There is no history of pain in the right hip before this morning. A detailed history was taken, including the current medications. Which drug might increase the risk of a non-traumatic hip fracture?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anticonvulsants Anticonvulsants like phenobarbital , carbamazepine , phenytoin , and valproate have been found to increase the risk of osteoporosis and, subsequently, nontraumatic fractures. Possible mechanisms explaining the association between anticonvulsants and bone loss include hepatic induction of cytochrome P450 enzymes (increases vitamin D catabolism), direct osteoblast inhibition, impaired calcium absorption , elevated homocysteine, inhibition of response to PTH, hyperparathyroidism, reduced reproductive sex hormones, and reduced vitamin K level.

Highyeild:

Etiology: Causes: These are multiple etiological factors responsible for osteoporosis. a. Age-Related b. Postmenopausal c. Lifestyle factors ● Alcohol abuse ● High salt intake ● Low calcium intake ● Vitamin D insufficiency ● Smoking (active and passive) ● Bedridden patient (Immobilization) d. Hypogonadal states like ● Androgen insensitivity ● Hyperprolactinemia ● Premature menopause e. Endocrine disorder ● Adrenal insufficiency ● Cushing's syndrome ● Diabetes mellitus types 1 and 2 ● Hyperparathyroidism ● Thyrotoxicosis f. Gastrointestinal disorder ● Celiac disease ● Inflammatory bowel diseases ● Malabsorption g. Hematologic disorders ● Multiple myeloma ● Sickle cell diseases ● Thalassemia h. Rheumatologic and autoimmune diseases ● Ankylosing spondylitis ● Rheumatoid arthritis i. Medications ● Aluminum (in antacids) ● Glucocorticoids (>5 mg/d) ● Anticoagulants (heparin) ● Prednisone or equivalent for >3 months ● Anticonvulsants ● Methotrexate

questions.text: The gold standard for the diagnosis of osteoporosis is which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry Dual - energy X - ray absorptiometry (DEXA) is a method developed originally for measuring bone density and mass . It is a procedure that measures the amount of calcium and other minerals in a bone by passing X-rays with two different energy levels through the bone. A dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry shows the strength and thickness of a bone and is usually done in the lower spine, hip, lower arm, wrist, fingers, and heel.

questions.text: A 56-year-old post-menopausal lady came to ortho OPD with a generalised body ache. She was receiving adjuvant aromatase inhibitor therapy for breast cancer. The Orthopaedician advised her to get Bone mineral density done, and her T score was -3.3. She was told that she has osteoporosis and is at high risk for fractures. She was prescribed Prolia 60 mg subcutaneously (SC) injections every 6 months and given calcium 1000 mg/day and vitamin D 400 IU/day. Identify the drug and mention its mechanism of action.

options.label: A
options.text: Nitrogen-containing Bisphosphonates – Inhibits farnesyl pyrophosphate synthase (FPPS)

options.label: C
options.text: Teriparatide – Anabolic drug which increases bone turnover and formation

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Denosumab – RANK Ligand inhibitor Antiresorptive drugs (e.g. bisphosphonates, estrogen, denosumab) reduce bone turnover by distinct mechanisms. Denosumab is a fully human monoclonal antibody that binds RANKL, preventing RANKL from activating RANK, its receptor on the osteoclast surface. With reduced RANK–RANKL binding, osteoclast formation, function and survival are inhibited, bone resorption decreases and bone mass increases. (Prolia is the famous brand name of Denosumab)

Highyeild:

In contrast to Denosumab , bisphosphonates bind bone minerals , where they are absorbed by mature osteoclasts, inducing osteoclast apoptosis and suppressing resorption. Nitrogen-containing Bisphosphonates – target a specific metabolic enzyme, farnesyl pyrophosphate synthase (FPPS), preventing the usual modification of intracellular proteins required for osteoclast function and survival. Option: C. Teriparatide is the Recombinant human parathyroid hormone (1–34) (20 μg/day), approved by the US FDA for treating post-menopausal osteoporosis and male osteoporosis secondary to hypogonadism. It is the first approved anabolic or bone-building drug where bone formation is stimulated more than resorption. Osteoblast formation is increased, and osteoblast apoptosis is inhibited, which increases bone turnover and formation. Therefore, intermittent administration increases the number of bone-forming osteoblasts, whereas continuous administration increases the number of bone-resorbing osteoclasts. Option: D.
